qas.question: What was the NAS primarily a base for?
What did the NAS Bermuda offer once designated Annex?

answers.text: anchorage and/or dockage facilities for transiting US Navy, US Coast Guard and NATO vessels

qas.question: What is located west of the NAS Annex?

answers.text: additional US Navy compound known as Naval Facility Bermuda

qas.question: What happened at the end of the Cold War?
What did US forces do in 1999?

context: <b4_0>The original NAS Bermuda<b4_0/> on the west side of the island, a <a0_0>seaplane<a0_0/> base until the mid-1960s, was designated as the <b5_0>Naval Air Station Bermuda Annex<b5_0/>. It provided optional <a1_0>anchorage and/or dockage facilities for transiting US Navy, US Coast Guard and NATO vessels<a1_0/>, depending on size. An <a2_0>additional US Navy compound known as <b7_0>Naval Facility Bermuda<a2_0/> (NAVFAC Bermuda)<b7_0/>, a SOSUS station, was located to the west of the Annex near a Canadian Forces communications facility. Although leased for 99 years, <a3_0><b6_0>US forces withdrew<b6_0/><a3_0/> in 1995, as part of the wave of base closures following the end of the Cold War.
